awd_titl_txt: Research and Development Support for Early Career Cartographers and Geospatial Scientists
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support travel for 25 early career researchers in the field of cartography and geographic information science (GIScience) to attend the 30th International Cartographic Conference (ICC). This project targets the professional development of early career scholars who are currently completing a graduate degree, or are in the early stages of their academic, professional career. The ICC covers all aspects of cartographic research and is an ideal scientific venue for young scholars to present their research and to talk face-to-face with an international community of scientists. The merit of this funding is evident from previous young scholars who have attended the ICC, as reflected in their scientific publications and funding awards to support research. The broader impact of this support for students and early career scholars is research innovation and collaboration that promotes future global leaders in cartography and GIScience from the United States.

Participation in the ICC will lead to the development of cutting-edge research and will enable U.S. scholars to take the lead in these endeavors. These young scholars develop new research agendas that investigate key scientific and societal challenges, promote collaboration with the international community, and disseminate advances in cartography and GIScience through workshops, seminars, and peer-reviewed publications. These accomplishments result in the development of more innovative and productive research in cartography and GIScience that serves the Nation’s interests regarding spatial information infrastructure. The event will provide new insights and approaches to cartographic research throughout the world, including the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Life of the Award

The International Cartographic Conference (ICC) is the biennial conference of the International Cartographic Association (ICA). Early career scholars (ECS) are students matriculating at U.S. institutions or who have completed their degree within the last five years. The NSF grant supported 14 US ECS to present a paper or poster at the 30th ICC held in Florence, Italy, from December 14-18, 2021. ECS were reimbursed up to $2,450 each for travel (for in-person attendees) and up to $150 for registration (for remote attendees during the COVID pandemic), for a total of $25,501. With a no-cost extension, the NSF grant also supported nine ECS to present a paper or poster at the 31st ICC in Cape Town, South Africa from August 13-18, 2023. ECS were reimbursed for travel up to $2,778 each for a total of $24,499.  All NSF funds have thus been spent.

 

Intellectual Merit

ECS research papers and posters were published in Advances in Cartography and GIScience of the ICA or Abstracts of the ICA. Furthermore, based on our 2024 survey of 33 ECS attending the last three ICCs (held in 2023, 2021, and 2019), ECS directly attributed 37 peer-reviewed journal articles and book chapters to research they had presented at an ICC. In addition to publications, ECS reported additional benefits directly related to ICC participation, including improvements in teaching influenced by their ICC participation; submitting proposals and being awarded grants; and meeting, exchanging ideas with, and collaborating with colleagues from other countries. ICC participation provided new ideas for some early career scholars’ thesis and dissertation research and facilitated the progress towards tenure and promotion for others.

 

Broader Impacts

The evidence of return on investment from this NSF grant through its impact on research and scholarly development is compelling in its application to short- and long-term scientific research, as well as the development of worldwide leaders in cartography and GIScience. Based on the results of our survey, most early career scholars have recently completed or are currently in a PhD program. Many have also secured funding to pursue research through a variety of grants, including grants from the NSF and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA). ECS have also assumed leadership roles in cartographic and GIScience societies and organizations, including ICA commissions and the Cartography and Geographic Information Society (CaGIS), American Association of Geographers (AAG), and North American Cartographic Information Society (NACIS). Additionally, US leaders in mid- to late-careers in the fields of cartography and GIScience who received NSF funding early in their careers to participate in an ICC have stressed the importance of their early-career ICC participation on their professional success.

 

The survey results also indicate that NSF-funded ECS well represent some underrepresented groups, especially first-generation college students and Asians. The United States National Committee for the ICA, which administers the grant, works hard to draw in new participation, especially among underrepresented groups (women, other ethnic minorities, persons with disabilities) and to foster their development as the future leaders in scholarly research and the global cartographic community.

 

Summary of Outcomes

The importance of ICC attendance on cartographic research and leadership for early career U.S. scholars is significant and compelling. In our survey, ECS indicated that the research they presented at an ICC led to the publication of peer-reviewed journal articles, improved teaching, resulted in grant approvals (including from the NSF and NGA), enabled them to take on leadership positions (within organizations such as the ICA, CaGIS, AAG, and NACIS), and resulted in honors and awards early in their career. Mid- to late-career scholars who were previously awarded NSF funding to participation in an ICC early in their careers also attribute their success to this funding and their conference participation.
